> I have a question for any of you that know the HyperNEAT code.  
> Basic=
ally I am trying to incorporate changing environmental conditions 
> into m=
y algorithm such that when a certain criteria is met the 
> environment I e=
valuate my evolved neural networks in is modified.  When 
> this happens I =
 want to throw out the fitness of all the individuals in 
> my population t=
hat were obtained from the old environment and force them 
> to be reevalua=
ted in the new environment.  Does anyone have a suggestion

can be done?
>

Hey Josh,

The ExperimentRun::evaluateP=
opulation(...) function is the one that loops through the population and as=
signs fitness to all the individuals based on the experiments.  There are s=
everal experiments so that the application can be multithreaded.

As long a=
s you aren't using MPI, all you have to do to change an experiment (or the =
environment, as you call it), is loop through all of your experiments in th=
e ExperimentRun class, dynamically cast the experiment to your specific exp=
eriment class, and call some function that changes the experiment in the fu=
ture.

It would be easiest to do this in between generations.  In this case=
, you wouldn't have to worry about re-evaluating individuals who have alrea=
dy received a fitness, although I supposed it could be done anytime.  If, d=
uring a call to evaluatePopulation, the environment needs to be updated, yo=
u'll have to write some code to abort the population evaluation and start i=
t over again, to ensure that the entire generation of individuals is evalua=
ted the same.

Jason G.
